Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Naomi Feldheim is "Applications of harmonic analysis to Gaussian stationary processes." The host institution for the fellowship is Stanford University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Amir Dembo.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Under this NSF postdoctoral fellowship, the PI investigated the long-term behavior of Gaussian stationary processes, which are a classical model of "stable noise" used in probability and applications. Together with my collaborators, we developed and applied analytic tools in order to study these random objects. Three papers were written during the fellowship's period, all of which were published or in advanced stages of revision in top journals. Those are:

  • "Persistence of Gaussian stationary processes: a spectral perspective", by N. Feldheim, O. Feldheim and S. Nitzan  (in revision)
  • "Exponential concentration for zeroes of stationary Gaussian processes" by R. Basu, A. Dembo, N. Feldheim and O. Zeitouni,  IMRN (rny277)
  • " On the Probability That a Stationary Gaussian Process With Spectral Gap Remains Non-negative on a Long Interval", by N. Feldheim, O. Feldheim, B. Jaye, F. Nazarov, S. Nitzan, IMRN (rny248).

During the period of the fellowship I have also worked on two other papers, which were initiated by discussions I had with visitors during my postdoc. The topic is unrelated to Gaussian processes, but yet again analytic methods are developed and used in order to solve a purely probabilistic question. Those are:

  • "Mean and Minimum of independent random variables", by N. Feldheim and O. Feldheim
  • "Convergence of the quantile admission process with veto power", by N. Feldheim and O. Feldheim  (to appear in Stoch. Proc. And Appl.)

Broader Impacts:  The NSF fellowship allowed me to spend two years in Stanford University and one summer in Weizmann institute, which were very significant for my career. I met with visitors, travelled myself to visit relevant scientists, participated in a few local and international events, heard the state-of-the art of probabilistic research in the seminar talks, organized the seminar for one term, and formed new connections which already have been proved to be fruitful. The fellowship undoubtedly advanced my career and my mathematical maturity, and prepared me for the tenure track position which I hold today in Bar-Ilan University. I feel very fortunate to have been awarded this NSF grant.
